source.citation: Berry, N. 2019. Investigating Factors that Influence Processor Productivity. B.For.Sc. (Hons) dissertation, University of Canterbury, NZ.
notes: Five mechanised cut-to-length crews (A–F) working in Kinleith Forest during 2018/19. Piece size (m³/stem) derived from STICKS data; processing times from video analysis.
Utilisation calculated using delays <10 min; reported utilisation across all crews = 91 %.
Intercept is not meaningful when piece size approaches zero but retained for completeness.
Reported crew-level average piece sizes ranged from 1.35 m³ (Crew C) to 2.05 m³ (Crews B and F).

categories.1: Poor – some large branching and/or slight sweep.
categories.2: Bad – large branching and/or severe sweep and/or multi-leader and/or forked stem.

notes: Berry (2019) reports that category 1 stems take 56 % longer than category 0, category 2 stems 84 % longer.

productivity_trend.description: Negative correlation between tree-form category and productivity (Figure 9). Regression not quantified beyond R² = 0.09; use processing-time multipliers to approximate penalties.

utilisation.productive_minutes_definition: Boom swing + delimbing + processing time; delays <10 min treated as utilisation loss.
